papers.abstract: Technology use in acute care has so far been studied with a predominant focus on safety and efficiency rather than the experience of acute care staff. In the present paper, we report a qualitative study including 130 hours of participant observation on acute care teams and retrospective interviews with nine anesthesiologists on their experiences with technology. Our approach is theoretically guided by four modern HCI perspectives, namely psychological need satisfaction, activity theory, embodied interaction, and media equation theory. We analyzed the interview and observation data using a reflexive thematic analysis and identified four themes. Technology as necessary (evil) describes the pervasiveness of technology and how acute care teams depend on technology. While technology as second patient covers the additional load for anesthesiologists on a functional and emotional level, technology as problem solver and safety net highlights relieving aspects of technology use. Technology as artificial limb focuses on so-called transparent tools that extend the body and capabilities of users. We then discuss the identified themes concerning the previously presented theories. Based on our findings and theoretical perspectives, we report general insights for research and design in acute care, such as the benefits of mixed methods or the importance of the gut feelings of experts. Finally, we propose possible directions for future work, such as developing a UX questionnaire adapted to the context of safety-critical domains, such as acute care.

events.Text: Technology use in acute care has so far been studied with a predominant focus on safety and efficiency rather than the experience of acute care staff.

Primary Object: so far the focus has been on safety and efficiency rather than the experience of acute care staff

Context: Technology use in acute care has so far been studied with a predominant focus on safety and efficiency rather than the experience of acute care staff.

events.Text: In the present paper, we report a qualitative study including 130 hours of participant observation on acute care teams and retrospective interviews with nine anesthesiologists on their experiences with technology. Our approach is theoretically guided by four modern HCI perspectives, namely psychological need satisfaction, activity theory, embodied interaction, and media equation theory. We analyzed the interview and observation data using a reflexive thematic analysis and identified four themes.

Agent: participants conducting the observation and interviewing anesthesiologists
Purpose: to provide insight into understanding among healthcare professionals concerning technology, especially within acute care teams and the experiences of anesthesiologists on their encounters with technology
Method: mixed-methods approach combining qualitative analysis with four theories from HCI literature
Results: our approach is theoretically guided by four modern HCI perspectives, namely psychological need satisfaction, activity theory, embodied interaction, and media equation theory. We analyzed the interview and observation data using a reflexive thematic analysis and identified four themes.

Additionally, we explored the relationships between the four themes across domains of experience and identified several common threads relating to technological affordances and barriers, psychological needs, situated interactions, and cultural contextualizations of technology in clinical practice.
Analysis: The integration of qualitative findings with theoretical constructs highlights the importance of considering human-centered design principles in healthcare technology development.
Implications: The findings imply that integrating these four themes into professional training and continuing education programs for anesthesiologists could lead to improved understanding and better management of technology-related challenges in clinical practice. Furthermore, addressing the identified gaps in current methodologies could inform the development of more robust evaluation frameworks for future technologies in healthcare.

events.Text: Technology as necessary (evil) describes the pervasiveness of technology and how acute care teams depend on technology. While technology as second patient covers the additional load for anesthesiologists on a functional and emotional level, technology as problem solver and safety net highlights relieving aspects of technology use. Technology as artificial limb focuses on so-called transparent tools that extend the body and capabilities of users. We then discuss the identified themes concerning the previously presented theories.

Based on our findings and theoretical perspectives, we report general insights for research and design in acute care, such as the benefits of mixed methods or the importance of the gut feelings of experts. Finally, we propose possible directions for future work, such as developing a UX questionnaire adapted to the context of safety-critical domains, such as acute care.

Primary Object: a UX questionnaire adapted to the context of safety-critical domains

papers.abstract: Socially assistive robots play an effective role in children's therapy and education. Robots engage children and provide interaction that is free of the potential judgment of human peers and adults. Research in socially assistive robots for children generally focuses on therapeutic and educational outcomes for those children, informed by a vision of autonomous robots. This perspective ignores therapists and educators, who operate these robots in practice. Through nine interviews with individuals who have used robots to deliver socially assistive services to neurodivergent children, we (1) define a dual-cycle model of therapy that helps capture the domain expert view of therapy, (2) identify six core themes of teleoperator needs and patterns across these themes, (3) provide high-level guidelines and detailed recommendations for designing teleoperated socially assistive robot systems, and (4) outline a vision of robot-assisted therapy informed by these guidelines and recommendations that centers teleoperators of socially assistive robots in practice.

events.Text: Through nine interviews with individuals who have used robots to deliver socially assistive services to neurodivergent children, we (1) define a dual-cycle model of therapy that helps capture the domain expert view of therapy, (2) identify six core themes of teleoperator needs and patterns across these themes, (3) provide high-level guidelines and detailed recommendations for designing teleoperated socially assistive robot systems, and (4) outline a vision of robot-assisted therapy informed by these guidelines and recommendations that centers teleoperators of socially assistive robots in practice.

Secondary Object: to gather insights and document findings

Context: This led to the definition of a dual-cycle model of therapy, identification of core themes, provision of guidelines, and outlining a vision for robot-assisted therapy.
Implications: Outlining a vision for robot-assisted therapy centered on these guidelines.
